title: ISTH Criteria for Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
description: Diagnoses overt disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) based on laboratory parameters. This scoring system was developed by the International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis (ISTH) as a standardized approach to DIC diagnosis using readily available laboratory tests. Use only in patients with clinical suspicion for DIC in appropriate clinical settings.

parameters.name: fibrin_marker
parameters.description: Fibrin-related marker elevation (e.g., D-dimer, fibrin monomers, FDP)

parameters.name: pt_prolongation
parameters.description: Prothrombin time (PT) prolongation beyond normal range

ranges.interpretation: Score <5 points: Not suggestive of overt DIC. May indicate non-overt DIC or absence of DIC. Consider reassessment if clinical suspicion remains high or clinical condition changes.
Score ≥5 points: Compatible with overt DIC. Strong likelihood of overt DIC. Consider immediate treatment and management of underlying condition. Monitor closely and repeat laboratory studies.

references: Taylor FB Jr, Toh CH, Hoots WK, Wada H, Levi M; Scientific Subcommittee on Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) of the International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis (ISTH). Towards definition, clinical and laboratory criteria, and a scoring system for disseminated intravascular coagulation. Thromb Haemost. 2001 Nov;86(5):1327-30.

Toh CH, Hoots WK; SSC on Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation of the ISTH. The scoring system of the Scientific and Standardisation Committee on Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation of the International Society on Thrombosis and Haemostasis: a 5-year overview. J Thromb Haemost. 2007 Mar;5(3):604-6.

Bakhtiari K, Meijers JC, de Jonge E, Levi M. Prospective validation of the International Society of Thrombosis and Haemostasis scoring system for disseminated intravascular coagulation. Crit Care Med. 2004 Dec;32(12):2416-21.

Levi M, Toh CH, Thachil J, Watson HG. Guidelines for the diagnosis and management of disseminated intravascular coagulation. British Committee for Standards in Haematology. Br J Haematol. 2009 Apr;145(1):24-33.
formula: Sum of points: Platelet count (0-2) + Fibrin marker (0-3) + PT prolongation (0-2) + Fibrinogen level (0-1)
notes: Use only in patients with clinical suspicion for DIC
Requires underlying disorder associated with DIC (malignancy, sepsis, obstetric complications, trauma)
Score ≥5 points indicates overt DIC with 91-93% sensitivity and 97-98% specificity
Score <5 does not rule out DIC but may indicate non-overt DIC
Serial measurements may be more useful than single assessment
D-dimer is the most commonly used fibrin-related marker
Consider clinical context and repeat testing if suspicion remains high
